title: Water emergency affects UNC-Chapel Hill campus
text:
SEND EMAIL An Orange Sewer and Water Authority employee look at the water break damage in Chapel Hill, Friday, Feb. 3, 2017, in N.C., officials in Chapel Hill are asking everybody to stop using water after the water main break and a low tank levels. Bottled water is being rushed to student dorms at North Carolina¬ís flagship public university and nearby nursing homes after a series of malfunctions shut down the municipal water system. Restaurants, schools in Chapel Hill and Carrboro and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill closed Friday after a water treatment plant was shut down by a miscue in chemical treatment and a water main broke. (Photo: Bernard Thomas, The Herald-Sun via AP) 
An extreme water shortage on the UNC-Chapel Hill campus and the surrounding Orange County area has prompted the shutdown of local schools and businesses. Water emergency in Orange County, here's the areas OWASA serves. Updating the #breakingnews here: https://t.co/9WRRTnUnTB pic.twitter.com/rBYCSNfYk0 
‚Äî ABC11 EyewitnessNews (@ABC11_WTVD) February 3, 2017 
The water supply became dangerously scarce Friday due to the breakage of a major water main and an accidental oversaturation of fluoride during the water treatment process, according to ABC11 Eyewitness News . 
The university posted an alert that included information about bottled water distribution: 
‚ÄúCampus housing officials are communicating directly by email with residential students and continue to encourage them to leave campus for the weekend if they are able. Community offices will remain open as normal. The University has arranged for portable toilets to be placed near residence and dining halls. They began arriving late this afternoon and will continue to be delivered tonight. The port-o-johns will include light stanchions for safety as it gets dark. Housing officials also will distribute bottled water at the Rams Head Dining Hall during the hours it is open. Additional American With Disabilities Act (ADA)-compliant port-o-johns also will be delivered.‚Äù 
The university has been sending text alerts and posting updates on its various social media accounts ‚Äî some with urgent warnings, others more light-hearted. The Pit Stop will OPEN tomorrow from 12pm ‚Äì 3pm and provide free lunch items to those in need, while supplies last! 
‚Äî UNC Student Stores (@StudentStores) February 3, 2017 Update to the update: Rams is re-opening for dinner! We're open from 5PM to 8PM ‚Äì come get some! üòã pic.twitter.com/c22Ib2MZLJ 
‚Äî Carolina Dining (@CDSatUNC) February 3, 2017 
Ed Kerwin, executive director of Orange Water and Sewer Authority, said the water main break resulted in the loss of approximately 1.5 million gallons of clean drinking water. 
People have been advised to avoid using the water under any circumstance due to the uncertainty of its safety. ‚ö†Ô∏è Do NOT drink campus water! @OrangeHealthNC has issued a Do Not Drink order ‚ö†Ô∏è https://t.co/Pj8OwrdXmi 
‚Äî UNC-Chapel Hill (@UNC) February 3, 2017 Water fountains are bagged at @UNC & Student Center's closing early. There's   Hill, State of Emergency issued #abc11 pic.twitter.com/FZZTU13gKq 
‚Äî Elaina Athans (@AthansABC11) February 3, 2017 
Friday classes were cancelled for UNC students, and the UNC‚Äôs scheduled men‚Äôs basketball game versus Notre Dame has been moved from 6 p.m. on Saturday to 1 p.m. on Sunday. 
Of course, students ‚Äî and others ‚Äî took their thoughts on the situation to Twitter. I told my grandma that if kids in Flint haven't had clean water in years, I can do it for a weekend in Chapel Hill. She hung up on me. üôÉ 
‚Äî Ashlynn Hampton (@ashlynn_hampton) February 4, 2017 everyone in chapel hill rn pic.twitter.com/vKQ6aSvzEB 
‚Äî Noa Havivi (@nmhavivi) February 3, 2017 Pic of me enjoying my Friday evening in chapel hill pic.twitter.com/EMvEqmdH84 
‚Äî jess kincaid (@_Jessplease) February 3, 2017 Me 20 years from now: "I lived through the Chapel Hill water crisis of 2017" 
‚Äî Mr. President2044 (@tarikwoods1) February 3, 2017 All of Chapel Hill right now, just sitting here without water‚Ä¶ even MJs tears be lookin tasty #WaterIsLife pic.twitter.com/ZzvorXu9Fs 
‚Äî Shaili J (@shaili3) February 4, 2017 Chapel Hill is just four hours into a water shortage, and I have seen Snapchats of people boiling pasta in Powerade. Please make a sandwich. 
‚Äî Alison Krug (@alisonkrug) February 3, 2017 
Emergency supplies of bottled water are being distributed throughout the area, with a priority on critical services such as fire suppression and nursing homes, according to the Orange County Emergency Services Director Dinah Jeffries. 
Until the issue is resolved, there are locations set up for the public to access bottled water for drinking, cooking and personal hygiene. 
‚Äî ABC11 EyewitnessNews (@ABC11_WTVD) February 3, 2017 
According to the Orange County Health Department, it will likely take at least 24 hours to determine the safety of the water. Questions about the OWASA water situation? Public Information line is 919-245-6111. 
‚Äî Orange County Health (@OrangeHealthNC) February 3, 2017 Cameron McGough is a student at the University of Kansas and a USA TODAY College digital producer.
